title: UK backs out of Saudi prison deal
text:
UK backs out of Saudi prison deal as pressure mounts Kate Allen and Sarah Neville in London ©Reuters 
The UK government is facing pressure over its relationship with Saudi Arabia after it backed out of a prisons training contract as signs of a cabinet split began to emerge. 
Under the £5.9m deal, British civil servants would have trained their Saudi counterparts. It was opposed by justice secretary Michael Gove, whose predecessor Chris Grayling had pursued the contract. Tory sources said the policy was initiated by his predecessor Ken Clarke. More Lawyers attack offshore tax evasion plans 
The spokeswoman for David Cameron, prime minister, said: “This bid has been reviewed and the government has decided that we won’t be proceeding.” 
The government submitted its final bid in April and discussions about it were continuing until recently. Other cabinet members including foreign secretary Philip Hammond are understood to have initially supported the contract, arguing that it would help to cement Britain’s relationship with Saudi Arabia. 
A separate contract to train Saudi police officers in the UK is still in place . 
The decision to withdraw the bid came after Mr Gove in September shut down Just Solutions International, a scheme to sell civil servants’ expertise to foreign governments on a commercial footing. 
Lord Falconer, a former Labour lord chancellor, has written to the National Audit Office, calling on it to investigate the sums spent on JSI and alleging “a lack of transparency” over its structures and funding. 
He asked Sir Amyas Morse, head of the NAO, to ensure “that the interests of the taxpayers have been properly safeguarded in this case and to provide guidance for such activities in future”. 
Liberal Democrat peer Lord Lester this week called on Theresa May, home secretary, to publish the details of her department’s relationship with Saudi Arabia, while human rights campaigners Amnesty International said “many questions remain unanswered”. 
Controversy over the justice contract has been brewing for months. 
Solicitor and Financial Times legal columnist David Allen Green — who has been scrutinising the deal since the start of this year — called on the government to publish the memoranda of understanding that set out “the key relationship” between the two countries on criminal justice and human rights matters. 
“The lack of transparency means we do not know what the agreed processes and arrangements are,” he said. “Until [they] are disclosed, it is difficult to accept at face value UK assurances about championing human rights in Saudi Arabia.” 
Lord Falconer told the FT: “We haven’t seen any accounts in relation to [JSI], we don’t know how it carried on its business and, perhaps most significantly, we don’t know the extent to which public money was used to fund the bids.”
